title: Can I file bankruptcy on a judgment when I signed a forbearance agreement?
question: I agree to pay on a judgment and I didn't pay and now the they are garnishing my wages for 5 times what I agree to pay them
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud
answers: Simple: YES. ANY DEBT must be listed in any bankruptcy. Whether that debt is dischargeable, whether you own a house and whether the judgment is a lien against and whether it can be voided are all other issues...but important ones. I agree with the responses from my colleagues and add the following: A judgment can be discharged like any other unsecured debt provided there was no fraud involved in getting the loan to begin with. If there were any irregularities on your part in the transaction, and those can be proven in the bankruptcy court, the debt might be declared "non-dischargeable", meaning you would still owe it. Bankruptcy is not filed on specific debts. You either file bankruptcy or you don't and all assets and debts get listed in any bankruptcy filing.

I believe the question you are trying to ask is whether or not the debt on which the Judgment was entered is dischargeable in a bankruptcy case. That depends on the type of debt and the specific findings of the court in the judgment. The forebearance agreement does not affect anything.

Certain debts are excepted from discharge in bankruptcy, such as recent tax debt, student loans, debts incurred through fraud, and others. So without specific information on the type of debt and what findings the court made, there is no way to answer your question.

The best thing to do is schedule a consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your state and you can then learn all your options and what you can accomplish by filing.

Your questions is a little vague, but, yes, generally, if you have a judgment against you and you default on a payment plan you set up then you can file bankruptcy to eliminate the judgment. The type of bankruptcy best suited for you will depend a lot on what assets you own and your income, as well as whether you are married and/or have dependents. Ideally you would qualify for a chapter 7 which would stop the garnishment and allow you to eliminate the judgment as well as any other unsecured debt. You want to make sure the judgment is not secured to any real property you may own. Speak with an experienced bankruptcy attorney to discuss your options.
